legislation.statute: Wisconsin enacted Act 9 in 1999; the first state to introduce a RPS without having restructured its electric-utility industry. Originally the RPS required 2.2% of electricity sold to be from renewables by 2012. In 2006, the goal was increased to 10% by 2015. Providers can petition the Public Service Commission to extend the compliance deadline.

rps_tech_details.name: Eligible Technologies
rps_tech_details.description: Photovoltaics, Wind, Biomass, Biodiesel, Hydroelectric, Solar Water Heat, Solar Thermal Electric, Solar Thermal Process Heat, Geothermal Electric, Geothermal Heat Pumps, Landfill Gas, Municipal Solid Waste, Biogas, Anaerobic Digestion, Tidal Energy, CHP/Cogeneration, Fuel Cells using Renewable Fuels

rps_tech_details.name: Geographic Eligibility
rps_tech_details.description: Renewable energy generated outside of Wisconsin is eligible, but only if the utility delivers it to customers in-state.

rps_tech_details.name: Sectors
rps_tech_details.description: Utility, Investor-Owned Utility, Municipal Utility, Rural Electric Cooperative

legislation.carveouts: The chart below is a carve-out breakdown for the RPS, also demonstrating overall ramp-up.
legislation.cost_cap_details: Wisconsin does not have an explicit cost cap

overview: 9.57% of the state's energy consumption must be from renewable sources by 2015
snapshot.policy_trajectory: Most states define a pathway to 'ramp-up' the amount of renewable energy that must be sold. This chart shows Colorado's policy pathway.
snapshot.summary: Wisconsin's Renewable Portfolio Standard (RPS) establishes a minimum amount of renewable energy that must be sold by the state's electricity providers. This page identifies and describes the features of the RPS and how they work together to define the minimum amount of renewable energy that will be sold in Wisconsin.
